strategy: try to evaluate the time of task accomplishment,and allocate tasks when they are in low fatigue.
strategyChange: sure,it is because when condition changed the thing I focus changed, so I try to change strategy to keep stress less and score more
stressFB: Yes, as it is a more intuitive method of increasing success to gain scores compared to making a assumption and estimating the rate of success by the portion of working time.

strategy: Wait to the stress percentage to go down
strategyChange: Yes, because in the absence of a stress indicator, I focused more on success score.

strategy: I first dispatch task to all operators and try to estimate their speed of stress recovery and task completing, then i try to dispatch more tasks on the better performance operator and try to dispatch less task to other lower performance one. Because this scenario have stress and sucess and score rate, i don't actually know their relation so i try to observe and found it out.
strategyChange: yes, because i can see different data of each operator like their stress and sucess rate, so i have to change my strategy e.g. it used to have stress graph which change simutaneously , but then the next scenerio changed it to a pending update one which cause me have to give everyone operator a try in order to calculate speed of each one, wasting some score.
stressFB: Yes, because the stress level is related  to the operator's task sucess rate, if a operator have a score arte of 99% but the stress is at 90 %, it is possible to waste the task, time and score on this operators, so i think stress feedback is important because it decide whether you can get a score or not.
prefLiteral: The stress graph have 2 important data for me, one is % of stress and other is level(low,medium,high), i think if the stress is at 30 % and the '30%' was able to be inlined as green, the level below it, 'low' such also be inlined as green .
prefSymbolic: To add the sucess rate so that i can calculate fast, and the stress graph can add a overall % above the graph so that i won't have to wait and estimate how long the stress level goes down to 'low' level.
combinations: a stress board from Literal with sucess rate and score rate board , remove thetask history and replace by others board like stress graph from symbolic.
remarks: Sometime the operator status board was cover by others operator's status board, it would be better to fix that. Also the table is not large enough, there were few times where i drop some box on the floor and it respawn on the top, the table were full of boxs and the box were drop into the operator's black box, it would be better to have ab igger table and just turn the table into a bucket so thing inside won't fell out.

strategy: Focused on giving one or two operators time to rest while the others are working. focused on assigning tasks after stress levels went below 35-40%.
strategyChange: Yes, when I have the stress I can focus mainly on that. But when I don't I have to focus on multiple other thing such as: Success/Failure and score.

strategy: I assigned tasks to the operators who were less stressed. I made sure to give all operators a rest in-between the tasks.
strategyChange: No. My strategy remained the same because I tried to ensure that all the operators tasks and rest were well balanced.
stressFB: Absolutely. As a team leader it would be useful to have an indicator of the stress levels of your team members. Otherwise, you might keep assigning tasks to an operator that is highly stressed and this will impact the success of the task completion.
prefLiteral: The numeric representation of the score and success rates.
prefSymbolic: I liked how the stress levels were represented in a graph format. It was easy to track the current and past stress levels.
combinations: Everything in the Literal Visualization should remain the same except for the stress levels. Replace the stress level representation of the Literal Visualization with that of the Symbolic Visualization.

strategy: I keep the stress level on MEDIUM and assign more tasks. They compensate one another.

stressFB: yes because it is the meter to evaluate their performance

prefSymbolic: Graphs and charts
combinations: Depending on the display data. For evaluating elements such as score, success rates, stress level, charts and graphs are better while numeric elements such as task history, task in queue should be literal. Hybrid elements can be the progress bars.

strategy: Tried to throw tasks at the operators that were least stressed or had stress decreasing. Initially gave it to only yellow stress indicators, but then gave it to all that were decreasing (and red).
strategyChange: Conditions with stress indicators I tended to assign tasks to operators that were the least stressed. Stress (symbolic) made me more empathetic towards the operators than other conditions; however, tasks were more stressful to manage.
stressFB: Yes, to be empathetic towards operators; otherwise they can get overworked.
prefLiteral: It made me look less toward the stress levels and maybe more throughput of tasks were achieved - I can't be sure though.
prefSymbolic: Made me more empathetic towards the operators.
combinations: Probably stress visualisation.
remarks: The representation of task management was interesting (using VR) and throwing tasks in an embodied way.

strategy: When their success is very high then i assign more to them. when the success rate is same, then i check the color and number of the stress level. if the stress level is low, then i assign the task to the lower one.
strategyChange: yes, then there is not stress level showing, then i have to rely on the increasing and descreasing of the success level to judge it. when it have the stress level then i will rely on the stress level and success level without assign some testing tasks to make the judgement.
stressFB: yes, it will tell if the success rate increasing or decreasing

remarks: would be better to highlight the final task success score is based on the success rate in the game. personally, I would prefer the combination of the literal and symbolic such as success rate, score and stress using literal but the all completion tasks and current tasks using symbol. I feel the timer to reduce to which level could change to the symbolic, because it is less likely will read them all at once for me. having a visual assistant would help rather than reading them.

strategy: I checked stress rate almost all the time and then the task distribution. one reason is that they are visually dominating so they grabbed more of my attention. and knowing stress is made available (compared to not having it - could have been influenced by my previous condition a bit) made me paid more attention at the beginning. but I think visual domination of stress level distribution might have influenced me paid more attention throughout the task
strategyChange: yes. i usually look at stress level first when its available then the score and success when stress is not available. I think stress level is usually very visually dominating to me so i am dawned to see it more often but it also help me judge how my operator works. Success and score would be the second items i refer to equally as it tells me how i should assign tasks to each operator.  i sometimes looks at current task and history to evenly distribute them but i don't find it crucial and i only do that when my operators are all loaded.
stressFB: yes. it is something i primarily rely on because its visually easy to understand as a reference. but i think anything that is design visually dominating to me among stress/success/score i will pay attention to all three.
prefLiteral: no
prefSymbolic: yes
combinations: i like task queue literal, stress level success and score symbolic. so when i refer to those it doesnt cover up the entire screen which sometimes is distracting and visually exhausting. to the point sometimes i shut down and go blind on certain information i found too "busy".
remarks: I think its a very interesting task and system. i personally think the visual design might have influenced how i prioritize information as they are not equally distributed the same size/color/motion so certain information gets my attention. but if you wanted to emphasize certain information i think its a good design to capture my attention on stress level for sure. :P

strategy: I tried my luck and kept all of the workers at around 50% task completion chance, buy timing single tasks to be completed at around the 55% threshold.
strategyChange: When there was a stress indicator I only used that to distribute tasks. When there was no stress indicator I used the failure/score to indicate when to assign a task and when to wait for their stress level to reduce.
stressFB: Yes. Although it felt like "cheating" a bit because in the real world you wouldn't be able to see the stress level of workers. Its important for these tasks I think because I could more easily balance out the task work load.
prefLiteral: I think I can understand percentages and numbers (especially success / score) a lot easier than pie graphs.
prefSymbolic: The stress level graph was clearer to read for me than a simple percentage number and I could also see a bit in the past of their stress level.

prefLiteral: Some information were easier to read.
prefSymbolic: Stress graph!!
combinations: Keep non-crucial information (such as task history) as text - everything else should be visual
remarks:
Pretty cool simulation! My only concerns were framerate and the cubes. The low framerate made me a bit sick, and the cubes were a bit hard to handle - throwing them would sometimes fail and also their constant movement when there are too many of them is distracting. I'd also disable any feedback (particles+vibration) *unless* it actually hits an operator or fall into a basket (as a confirmation if you will).
Other than that, had fun playing around with it :p

strategy: I primarily focused on their stress level. I identified some gained stress slower or lost stress faster so I would essentially rotate through the workers and give them a task if I thought they could complete that task without their stress getting too high. Generally if they were in the low 20% or below I would give them a task, sometimes two if they were very low stress.
strategyChange: Yes, without the stress indicator I had to look for other insights from the other data. I thought perhaps the animations indicated stress though I realized this was not the case quite quickly in the conditions with the stress indicators. When there was not stress indicators I typically looked at how often a worker was failing a task, often watching to see how the number/graphic changed so I could try to guess their stress level.
stressFB: Yes, I think without them there was a lot of guess work. I could only really tell if a worker was stressed by when they failed tasks or didn't.
prefLiteral: I found keeping track of success rate and score easier in the literal conditions. I also liked seeing the history of their stress levels as it was sometimes clearer than keeping track of a graph. I also found it easier to use the task queue in the literal conditions.
prefSymbolic: I preferred the graph for stress, although the text in the literal condition was easy to read I liked to be able to visualize the rate of change of stress so I could approximate how high it might go with each task.
combinations: I think I would include the % number alongside the stress graph and the successes and failures. I would also probably use the task queue from the literal visualizations.
remarks: This was a very interesting and engaging study! I really enjoyed it!

prefLiteral: Having the written information available to read quickly
prefSymbolic: the boxes looked cool
combinations: Literal with the addition of the graph

strategy: I assigned tasks based on the stress level increasing rate of each operator.
strategyChange: Yes I focus more on recognizing each participants' strength and weakness without stress indicator. Because I do not have a clear feedback about the stress level of operators reacting to an assigned task.
stressFB: Yes. It is a very useful metric to reflect an employee's competency to different task.
prefLiteral: Communication between supervisor and operators. Have a better insight of operators' stress level.
prefSymbolic: Real time monitoring their stress level in the workplace to better understand their status.
combinations: I would prefer both symbolic and literal stress indicator. It helps me better understand the status of each operator in a team.

strategy: Mainly looking at the stress graph and trying to extrapolate from it whether the operator will handle a new task successfully.
strategyChange: My strategy changed in every condition I believe, depending on the available information (stress or no stress), but also because of how fast and how easy it was to read the information.
stressFB: Definitely yes. Especially the graph. Tells how fast operators begin stressing and makes it much easier for the manager to choose to give tasks to.
prefLiteral: Some information were easier to read.
prefSymbolic: Stress graph!!
combinations: Keep non-crucial information (such as task history) as text - everything else should be visual
remarks:
Pretty cool simulation! My only concerns were framerate and the cubes. The low framerate made me a bit sick, and the cubes were a bit hard to handle - throwing them would sometimes fail and also their constant movement when there are too many of them is distracting. I'd also disable any feedback (particles+vibration) *unless* it actually hits an operator or fall into a basket (as a confirmation if you will).
Other than that, had fun playing around with it :p

strategy: watching the stress plot to assign the tasks
strategyChange: no, i always keep tracking the successful rate and the stress, and it help me a lot
stressFB: yes, when the stress goes up, i can see the successful rate goes down, and if i don't have the feedback on the stress, the only matrix is the successful rate and the task queue.
prefLiteral: task queue, success/failure, score
prefSymbolic: stress
combinations: stress, success/failure

strategy: try to increase the score of each while considering the stress level as a chance of success. Wait stress to go down before reallocating tasks<
strategyChange: Yes. Try to guess the stress and the probability of increasing score with other information such as portion of time and task queue
stressFB: Yes to guess the positive impact of the task allocation on the score
prefLiteral: Score value
prefSymbolic: curve of stress with colors
combinations: keep literal score and stress curve

strategy: I generally checked to see if a worker was at low stress and how many tasks they had remaining. I noticed some workers would gain stress more quickly so I tended to space out dispatching tasks to them to give them time to rest while prioritizing those that gained stress less quickly. If a worker was very low stress and gained it slowly I would give them multiple tasks at a time.
strategyChange: Yes, without the stress indicator I had to look for other insights from the other data. I thought perhaps the animations indicated stress though I realized this was not the case quite quickly in the conditions with the stress indicators. When there was not stress indicators I typically looked at how often a worker was failing a task, often watching to see how the number/graphic changed so I could try to guess their stress level.
stressFB: Yes, I think without them there was a lot of guess work. I could only really tell if a worker was stressed by when they failed tasks or didn't.
prefLiteral: I found keeping track of success rate and score easier in the literal conditions. I also liked seeing the history of their stress levels as it was sometimes clearer than keeping track of a graph. I also found it easier to use the task queue in the literal conditions.
prefSymbolic: I preferred the graph for stress, although the text in the literal condition was easy to read I liked to be able to visualize the rate of change of stress so I could approximate how high it might go with each task.
combinations: I think I would include the % number alongside the stress graph and the successes and failures. I would also probably use the task queue from the literal visualizations.
remarks: This was a very interesting and engaging study! I really enjoyed it!

strategy: Make the success and score not too low.
strategyChange: Yes, since different representations have different intuitive feeling for me, this has led to a change in focus of my cognition.
stressFB: Yes, it's about the efficiency of the error rate.
prefLiteral: straightforward and simple
prefSymbolic: beautiful and three-dimensional
combinations: May be Literal.

strategy: Allocate more tasks for the faster one as possible as they can gain higher results with less fatigue
strategyChange: sure,it is because when condition changed the thing I focus changed, so I try to change strategy to keep stress less and score more
stressFB: Yes, as it is a more intuitive method of increasing success to gain scores compared to making a assumption and estimating the rate of success by the portion of working time.
prefLiteral: Task queue and history as if it is too outstanding ,it might impact your focus and the speed you made decision.
prefSymbolic: success and stress, since it is very intuitive to estimate your current results
combinations: Task queue,Current task completion, All task completion, and task history-literal and the other things could be symbolic.
remarks: If it is possible, I prefer the redesign of component,  the most frequently used part(for example,  I really prefer using the stress, the score,etc) could be highlighted or resized larger while the less frequently used part like Task history ,which can be indirectly used to estimate the stress, can be resized smaller or removed.

strategy: Give tasks to operators with the highest success rate who were not busy
strategyChange: Yes, because in the absence of a stress indicator, I focused more on success score.
stressFB: Yes, as the coordinator, I appreciated knowing how stress operators were.
prefLiteral: The scores are best as a number because you can remember them easier.
prefSymbolic: The stress chart was great help and gives a sense of how fats stress increases/decreases.
combinations: Both stress and success score could be both literal and symbolic.

strategy: at first i dispatch tasks to all operator to estimate their speed of stress recovery and task completing speed. then i will try to dispatch more task to the better performance one and try to keep it's sucess rate above 80 or 85 , in the meanwhile those lower performance operators will be dispatched task between the time of the fastest operators completing tasks. It is a very common strategy on strategic video games and i use it many times.
strategyChange: yes, because i can see different data of each operator like their stress and sucess rate, so i have to change my strategy e.g. it used to have stress graph which change simutaneously , but then the next scenerio changed it to a pending update one which cause me have to give everyone operator a try in order to calculate speed of each one, wasting some score.
stressFB: Yes, because the stress level is related  to the operator's task sucess rate, if a operator have a score arte of 99% but the stress is at 90 %, it is possible to waste the task, time and score on this operators, so i think stress feedback is important because it decide whether you can get a score or not.
prefLiteral: The stress graph have 2 important data for me, one is % of stress and other is level(low,medium,high), i think if the stress is at 30 % and the '30%' was able to be inlined as green, the level below it, 'low' such also be inlined as green .
prefSymbolic: To add the sucess rate so that i can calculate fast, and the stress graph can add a overall % above the graph so that i won't have to wait and estimate how long the stress level goes down to 'low' level.
combinations: a stress board from Literal with sucess rate and score rate board , remove thetask history and replace by others board like stress graph from symbolic.
remarks: Sometime the operator status board was cover by others operator's status board, it would be better to fix that. Also the table is not large enough, there were few times where i drop some box on the floor and it respawn on the top, the table were full of boxs and the box were drop into the operator's black box, it would be better to have ab igger table and just turn the table into a bucket so thing inside won't fell out.

strategy: Watching the failure success/failure rate and how many tasks are in the queue
strategyChange: Yes, depending if I had a symbolic or non symbolic layout I used different features stronger or less
stressFB: yes, I would like to have an overview of the stress level has it helps to decide when to integrate breaks
prefLiteral: Less text, if literal then number based
prefSymbolic: easy understanding of the information provided, more intuitive
combinations: stress level in percentage, success/failure rate from literal environment (last one), task queue & history from literal because it's less confusing,
remarks: I would integrate "I liked" and "I don't liked" questions into each test questionnaire because it was harder for me to remember what specifically I preferred or not

strategy: Focused on the success failure to help figure out how stressed an operator is and that way I give them time to rest.
strategyChange: Yes, when I have the stress I can focus mainly on that. But when I don't I have to focus on multiple other thing such as: Success/Failure and score.
stressFB: Really helpful, helps predict next tasks success probability. And therefore, helps with assigning tasks or let operators rest.

prefSymbolic: The Stress levels

remarks: Try adding different skilled operators, and maybe rather than just success or failure (true or false) add the success rate of each task. (if an operator achieves 65 success of a task, it might increase their stress with the next task)

strategy: trying to keep a success rate above 50%

strategy: I assigned tasks based on the success and failure rate of past tasks. As the success rate increased I allocated more tasks but I still made sure to give a break to all the operators. Also, I assigned tasks based on the task queue. If the operator had less tasks to complete in task queue, I assigned one more depending on how fast the operator completed a task.
strategyChange: No. My strategy remained the same because I tried to ensure that all the operators tasks and rest were well balanced.
stressFB: Absolutely. As a team leader it would be useful to have an indicator of the stress levels of your team members. Otherwise, you might keep assigning tasks to an operator that is highly stressed and this will impact the success of the task completion.
prefLiteral: The numeric representation of the score and success rates.
prefSymbolic: I liked how the stress levels were represented in a graph format. It was easy to track the current and past stress levels.
combinations: Everything in the Literal Visualization should remain the same except for the stress levels. Replace the stress level representation of the Literal Visualization with that of the Symbolic Visualization.

strategy: I kept my focus on Score and Success rates
strategyChange: Depending on how data is visualized, the strategy will alter to adapt
stressFB: yes because it is the meter to evaluate their performance
prefLiteral: Numbers
prefSymbolic: Graphs and charts
combinations: Depending on the display data. For evaluating elements such as score, success rates, stress level, charts and graphs are better while numeric elements such as task history, task in queue should be literal. Hybrid elements can be the progress bars.

strategy: When operators were not working actively on a task I would throw tasks at them, sometimes I would check their success rate - but if they were the only one available I would throw them the task either way.
strategyChange: Conditions with stress indicators I tended to assign tasks to operators that were the least stressed. Stress (symbolic) made me more empathetic towards the operators than other conditions; however, tasks were more stressful to manage.
stressFB: Yes, to be empathetic towards operators; otherwise they can get overworked.
prefLiteral: It made me look less toward the stress levels and maybe more throughput of tasks were achieved - I can't be sure though.
prefSymbolic: Made me more empathetic towards the operators.
combinations: Probably stress visualisation.
remarks: The representation of task management was interesting (using VR) and throwing tasks in an embodied way.

strategy: based on the success rate to assign the tasks. If it is high, then assign more to the workers. When I assign one task to the work, if the success reduced to less than 20% then i will try to assign one more to see if the success rate increase or reduce. if it is continue reduce then i will assign the task to others. if it is increase, then i will continue to assign the tasks to that workers.
strategyChange: yes, then there is not stress level showing, then i have to rely on the increasing and descreasing of the success level to judge it. when it have the stress level then i will rely on the stress level and success level without assign some testing tasks to make the judgement.
stressFB: yes, it will tell if the success rate increasing or decreasing
prefLiteral: the stress level and success rate, and score
prefSymbolic: all completion tasks bar and current completion
combinations: all the completion task and current task
remarks: would be better to highlight the final task success score is based on the success rate in the game. personally, I would prefer the combination of the literal and symbolic such as success rate, score and stress using literal but the all completion tasks and current tasks using symbol. I feel the timer to reduce to which level could change to the symbolic, because it is less likely will read them all at once for me. having a visual assistant would help rather than reading them.

strategy: I check the success and score first before assigning task without stress level visualisation. i then give tasks based on how the overall score is (1st) then the success rate is (2nd). However i did have spare time to look at other data a bit more. I find them helpful to have but i dont think they are critical therefore i might not paying enough attention to them
strategyChange: yes. i usually look at stress level first when its available then the score and success when stress is not available. I think stress level is usually very visually dominating to me so i am dawned to see it more often but it also help me judge how my operator works. Success and score would be the second items i refer to equally as it tells me how i should assign tasks to each operator.  i sometimes looks at current task and history to evenly distribute them but i don't find it crucial and i only do that when my operators are all loaded.
stressFB: yes. it is something i primarily rely on because its visually easy to understand as a reference. but i think anything that is design visually dominating to me among stress/success/score i will pay attention to all three.
prefLiteral: no
prefSymbolic: yes
combinations: i like task queue literal, stress level success and score symbolic. so when i refer to those it doesnt cover up the entire screen which sometimes is distracting and visually exhausting. to the point sometimes i shut down and go blind on certain information i found too "busy".
remarks: I think its a very interesting task and system. i personally think the visual design might have influenced how i prioritize information as they are not equally distributed the same size/color/motion so certain information gets my attention. but if you wanted to emphasize certain information i think its a good design to capture my attention on stress level for sure. :P

strategy: percentage score for their completion of task

stressFB: Yes, as it's linked to success of tasks completed, as well as operator safety and wellbeing

strategy: Maintaining success rate and dispatch tasks to operators equally.

strategy: Identified the different speed operators so I only needed to look at one fast, one medium and one slow and assume that the other operator in the pair is at the same stress. I looked at portion of time mostly and waited until a percent for each. I made sure there wasn't already a task just incase I made mistake as I only wanted them to complete one task at a time.
strategyChange: Yes, the only thing you really needed with the stress conditions is stress. Without stress I needed to rely on a combination of other components.
stressFB: Yes, it makes it a lot easier to assign tasks to get the maximum score

prefSymbolic: The stress graph had a time aspect to it.
combinations: I would remove everything except the stress graph because that is all that is needed - and I like the stress graph more than just the number. The rest is just clutter when the stress indicator exists.

strategy: In this one I learnt the speeds of each worker and distributed tasks based on that, it took a few failures at the start to learn the speeds. I also watched the total work percentage as an indicator to each individual workers speed so I knew I was roughly dividing tasks correctly between each worker.
strategyChange: When there was a stress indicator I only used that to distribute tasks. When there was no stress indicator I used the failure/score to indicate when to assign a task and when to wait for their stress level to reduce.
stressFB: Yes. Although it felt like "cheating" a bit because in the real world you wouldn't be able to see the stress level of workers. Its important for these tasks I think because I could more easily balance out the task work load.
prefLiteral: I think I can understand percentages and numbers (especially success / score) a lot easier than pie graphs.
prefSymbolic: The stress level graph was clearer to read for me than a simple percentage number and I could also see a bit in the past of their stress level.
combinations: Symbolic Stress + Literal everything else. (And maybe keep the stress percentage on the symbolic stress as well).

The low framerate made me a bit sick, and the cubes were a bit hard to handle - throwing them would sometimes fail and also their constant movement when there are too many of them is distracting. remarks: would be better to highlight the final task success score is based on the success rate in the game. personally, I would prefer the combination of the literal and symbolic such as success rate, score and stress using literal but the all completion tasks and current tasks using symbol. I feel the timer to reduce to which level could change to the symbolic, because it is less likely will read them all at once for me. having a visual assistant would help rather than reading them.

strategy: I see who is sitting and waiting to be assigned first (all task completion). then i check whos bar charts (success and score) is higher. i assign tasks based on those criteria.
strategyChange: yes. i usually look at stress level first when its available then the score and success when stress is not available. I think stress level is usually very visually dominating to me so i am dawned to see it more often but it also help me judge how my operator works. Success and score would be the second items i refer to equally as it tells me how i should assign tasks to each operator.  i sometimes looks at current task and history to evenly distribute them but i don't find it crucial and i only do that when my operators are all loaded.
stressFB: yes. it is something i primarily rely on because its visually easy to understand as a reference. but i think anything that is design visually dominating to me among stress/success/score i will pay attention to all three.
prefLiteral: no
prefSymbolic: yes
combinations: i like task queue literal, stress level success and score symbolic. so when i refer to those it doesnt cover up the entire screen which sometimes is distracting and visually exhausting. to the point sometimes i shut down and go blind on certain information i found too "busy".
remarks: I think its a very interesting task and system. i personally think the visual design might have influenced how i prioritize information as they are not equally distributed the same size/color/motion so certain information gets my attention. but if you wanted to emphasize certain information i think its a good design to capture my attention on stress level for sure. :P

strategy: Score and success
strategyChange: yes, stress became more important in the last scenario, when it was represented visually
stressFB: Yes, as it's linked to success of tasks completed, as well as operator safety and wellbeing
prefLiteral: Success and scores
prefSymbolic: stress
combinations: Symbolic stress and literal success and scores
remarks: I couldn't read some fields during the simulations, e.g. time to complete task and task history. The tasks were clearly explained to me. All the best with the research!

strategy: distribute task one at a time and let them rest in between
strategyChange: yes, I was changing according to the different prompt
stressFB: yes, having feedback from the operator allows us to tell if he can work more or rest.
prefLiteral: better for unnecessary component since it takes less space and more accurate for stress
prefSymbolic: easier to tell what it is with a rapid look
combinations: none

strategy: Depend on the success rate chart and dispatch tasks.
strategyChange: Without stress level, I assigned the tasks based only on the success rate and score.
stressFB: In order to increase the success rate of the tasks, the stress level is only indicator.
prefLiteral: It is easy to notice the success/failure and score.
prefSymbolic: It is easy to notice task history and task queue. (easy to load balancing of tasks)
combinations: Literal condition (success/failure, score), Symbolic condition (task history, queue, stress level)

strategy: I looked at success rate and portion of time working, then tried to use them  both to calculate if I should assign another task.
strategyChange: Yes, the only thing you really needed with the stress conditions is stress. Without stress I needed to rely on a combination of other components.
stressFB: Yes, it makes it a lot easier to assign tasks to get the maximum score
prefLiteral: Numbers make it easier to read.
prefSymbolic: The stress graph had a time aspect to it.
combinations: I would remove everything except the stress graph because that is all that is needed - and I like the stress graph more than just the number. The rest is just clutter when the stress indicator exists.

strategy: I identified the fast workers and then gave them move time in between task assignment. I gave the slow workers more tasks.
strategyChange: When there was a stress indicator I only used that to distribute tasks. When there was no stress indicator I used the failure/score to indicate when to assign a task and when to wait for their stress level to reduce.
stressFB: Yes. Although it felt like "cheating" a bit because in the real world you wouldn't be able to see the stress level of workers. Its important for these tasks I think because I could more easily balance out the task work load.
prefLiteral: I think I can understand percentages and numbers (especially success / score) a lot easier than pie graphs.
prefSymbolic: The stress level graph was clearer to read for me than a simple percentage number and I could also see a bit in the past of their stress level.
combinations: Symbolic Stress + Literal everything else. (And maybe keep the stress percentage on the symbolic stress as well).

strategy: I attempted to assign tasks to those with a higher success rate.
strategyChange: For the conditions that had stress levels i assigned tasks based on operator stress levels and for conditions without stress levels i assigned tasks based on success rate.
stressFB: It helps to decided who to assign tasks
prefLiteral: Having the written information available to read quickly
prefSymbolic: the boxes looked cool
combinations: Literal with the addition of the graph

strategy: Pay attention on strength and weakness of operators
strategyChange: Yes I focus more on recognizing each participants' strength and weakness without stress indicator. Because I do not have a clear feedback about the stress level of operators reacting to an assigned task.
stressFB: Yes. It is a very useful metric to reflect an employee's competency to different task.
prefLiteral: Communication between supervisor and operators. Have a better insight of operators' stress level.
prefSymbolic: Real time monitoring their stress level in the workplace to better understand their status.
combinations: I would prefer both symbolic and literal stress indicator. It helps me better understand the status of each operator in a team.

strategy: I was looking on the portion of time working. If it seemed good enough for a specific operator then I would give them another task. I would estimate in my head the best "portion of time working" value for each operator based on feedback from the "success/failure" and "score" values.
strategyChange: My strategy changed in every condition I believe, depending on the available information (stress or no stress), but also because of how fast and how easy it was to read the information.
stressFB: Definitely yes. Especially the graph. Tells how fast operators begin stressing and makes it much easier for the manager to choose to give tasks to.
prefLiteral: Some information were easier to read.
prefSymbolic: Stress graph!!
combinations: Keep non-crucial information (such as task history) as text - everything else should be visual
remarks:
Pretty cool simulation! My only concerns were framerate and the cubes. The low framerate made me a bit sick, and the cubes were a bit hard to handle - throwing them would sometimes fail and also their constant movement when there are too many of them is distracting. I'd also disable any feedback (particles+vibration) *unless* it actually hits an operator or fall into a basket (as a confirmation if you will).
Other than that, had fun playing around with it :p

strategy: the successful rate
strategyChange: no, i always keep tracking the successful rate and the stress, and it help me a lot
stressFB: yes, when the stress goes up, i can see the successful rate goes down, and if i don't have the feedback on the stress, the only matrix is the successful rate and the task queue.
prefLiteral: task queue, success/failure, score
prefSymbolic: stress
combinations: stress, success/failure

strategy: Maximize score while allocating tasks by inferring stress level by the portion of time and history, try to memorize also the of choice on the score (increase or decrease)
strategyChange: Yes. Try to guess the stress and the probability of increasing score with other information such as portion of time and task queue
stressFB: Yes to guess the positive impact of the task allocation on the score
prefLiteral: Score value
prefSymbolic: curve of stress with colors
combinations: keep literal score and stress curve

strategy: I started by looking at their scores and success rate for their initial tasks, then attempted to identify their stress level by whether or not they failed the next task they were given. The ones that failed I left to rest and then tried to evenly space out tasks between everyone. Some workers seemed to work faster but also were failing more. One worker worked slower but seemed to succeed more often so I tended to prioritize them.
strategyChange: Yes, without the stress indicator I had to look for other insights from the other data. I thought perhaps the animations indicated stress though I realized this was not the case quite quickly in the conditions with the stress indicators. When there was not stress indicators I typically looked at how often a worker was failing a task, often watching to see how the number/graphic changed so I could try to guess their stress level.
stressFB: Yes, I think without them there was a lot of guess work. I could only really tell if a worker was stressed by when they failed tasks or didn't.
prefLiteral: I found keeping track of success rate and score easier in the literal conditions. I also liked seeing the history of their stress levels as it was sometimes clearer than keeping track of a graph. I also found it easier to use the task queue in the literal conditions.
prefSymbolic: I preferred the graph for stress, although the text in the literal condition was easy to read I liked to be able to visualize the rate of change of stress so I could approximate how high it might go with each task.
combinations: I think I would include the % number alongside the stress graph and the successes and failures. I would also probably use the task queue from the literal visualizations.
remarks: This was a very interesting and engaging study! I really enjoyed it!
